rhythms.name: 4x4
rhythms.description: Soleá is one of the foundational forms in Flamenco. It has a solemn and serious tone and is often used as a base for other forms.
rhythms.commonUsage: Soleá is used in both singing (cante) and dance (baile). It is a slow, reflective palo.

rhythms.name: Soleá
rhythms.description: Soleá is one of the foundational forms in Flamenco. It has a solemn and serious tone and is often used as a base for other forms.
rhythms.commonUsage: Soleá is used in both singing (cante) and dance (baile). It is a slow, reflective palo.

rhythms.name: Alegrías
rhythms.description: Alegrías is a joyful and festive palo, often associated with a lively atmosphere. It’s frequently used in celebratory performances.
rhythms.commonUsage: Alegrías is typically used in dance (baile) but also in singing (cante). It’s known for its upbeat rhythm.

rhythms.name: Bulerías
rhythms.description: Bulerías is fast and dynamic, often used for improvisation. It's one of the most popular palos in Flamenco.
rhythms.commonUsage: Bulerías is often used in both instrumental and dance performances, showcasing improvisational skills.

rhythms.name: Fandango
rhythms.description: Fandango is one of the most accessible and widely used palos in Flamenco. It has a moderate rhythm and is less complex than other palos.
rhythms.commonUsage: Fandango is commonly used in both instrumental and vocal performances, often performed in social gatherings.

rhythms.name: Tangos
rhythms.description: Tangos is a simple and danceable palo with a 4/4 time signature. It’s one of the most commonly performed palos in Flamenco.
rhythms.commonUsage: Tangos is used in both dance and song, and is a popular choice for beginners due to its simplicity.

rhythms.name: Siguiriyas
rhythms.description: Siguiriyas is one of the most dramatic and complex forms in Flamenco, known for its somber tone and intense emotion.
rhythms.commonUsage: Siguiriyas is primarily used for cante (singing), often performed in deeply emotional and reflective contexts.

rhythms.name: Rumba
rhythms.description: Rumba is a lighter, rhythmic palo with Afro-Cuban roots. It's popular for its relaxed, playful style and is often used in more modern Flamenco.
rhythms.commonUsage: Rumba is commonly used for both dance and vocal performances and is very accessible to beginners.

rhythms.name: Taranta
rhythms.description: Taranta is a palo in 4/4 time, often used for its emotional, expressive power. It is typically performed in a more serious, reflective manner.
rhythms.commonUsage: Taranta is used primarily for cante (singing) and is often performed in solemn contexts.

rhythms.name: Malagueña
rhythms.description: Malagueña is a palo in 12 beats, known for its flowing and lyrical rhythm. It's often associated with the coast of Andalusia.
rhythms.commonUsage: Malagueña is widely used in both cante (singing) and baile (dance), especially for its melodic and expressive nature.

rhythms.name: Bambino
rhythms.description: Bambino is a fast-paced, lively palo with 6 beats, often used for playful, upbeat performances.
rhythms.commonUsage: Bambino is used in dance performances, especially for light-hearted and energetic routines.

rhythms.name: Granadinas
rhythms.description: Granadinas is a palo with a smooth, lyrical feel and is often slower in tempo compared to other 12-beat palos.
rhythms.commonUsage: Granadinas is used in singing (cante) and is often performed in more introspective or romantic Flamenco pieces.
